title: 108_hr5250
content: The Act titled "Federal Flight Deck Officer Improvement Act of 2004" mandates training and requalification for Federal Flight Deck Officers. The Act "Federal Flight Deck Officer Improvement Act of 2004" requires a study on the feasibility of conducting initial training for Federal flight deck officers at various locations in the United States. A report on the study results must be submitted to the relevant committees within 180 days of the enactment of this provision. The Secretary must ensure that eligible pilots are given a choice of training dates with at least 30 days notice. A program will be established to improve travel access to training facilities. Qualification standards for requalification and recurrent training facilities will be set by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide free Federal flight deck officer training, requalification, and recurrent training to eligible pilots at diverse facilities, including military, law enforcement, and private training facilities meeting qualification standards. Travel expenses may be covered for pilots undergoing training. The Secretary will establish secure communication means for Federal flight deck officers and issue badges to them within 180 days of enactment. SEC. 3. FEDERAL FLIGHT DECK OFFICER FIREARM CARRIAGE PILOT PROGRAM. Section 44921(f) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to implement a pilot program allowing pilots in the Federal flight deck officer program to carry firearms on their persons. The Secretary may set training, equipment, and procedures for safety and weapon retention. A review of the pilot program's safety record will be conducted within a year of its initiation. The pilot program allows Federal flight deck officers to carry firearms. A review of the program's safety record will be conducted, and if deemed comparable to existing safety levels, all participating pilots may have the option to carry their firearm on their person. The President is encouraged to pursue agreements with foreign governments for Federal flight deck officers on international flights. A report on the status of these efforts must be submitted within 180 days. Additionally, compensation for program-related injuries is addressed. Section 44921 of title 49, United States Code is amended to include provisions for compensation for Federal flight deck officers who sustain injury or death while on duty. The Secretary is required to work with relevant Federal agencies to obtain compensation under applicable laws and submit a report to Congress within 180 days with recommendations for legislative actions if needed. Congress believes that air carriers should allow Federal flight deck officers to take leave for training. Section 44921 of title 49, United States Code is amended to replace references to the Under Secretary with the Secretary of Homeland Security.
